doc.title: Directive on Charging and Special Financial Authorities

clauses.clause: This directive takes effect on April 1, 2019.

This directive replaces the following Treasury Board policy instruments:
Policy on Interdepartmental Charging and Transfers Between Appropriations (June 20, 1997)
Policy on Special Revenue Spending Authorities (July 1, 2000)
Policy on Service Standards for External Fees (April 1, 2012)
Directive on Internal Support Services (April 1, 2012)
Directive on Specified Purpose Accounts (August 12, 2010)
Directive on Receipt, Deposit and Recording of Money (August 12, 2010)

Transitional considerations: Subsection 4.2.4 of this directive, including subsections 4.2.4.1, 4.2.4. 2, 4.2.4.3, 4.2.4.5 and 4.2.4. 7, takes effect on April 1, 2021.Subsections 4.2.5.1.1 and 4.2.6 will take effect on April 1, 2024.
This directive is issued pursuant to the authorities indicated in sections 7 and 39 of the Financial Administration Act.
This directive is issued pursuant to the authorities indicated in sections 4, 7, 17 and 20 of the Service Fees Act.
The objectives indicated in section 3 of the Policy on Financial Management apply to this directive.
The expected results indicated in section 3 of the Policy on Financial Management apply to this directive.

The chief financial officers (CFOs) are responsible for the following:
Ensuring that the revenue from charging is recorded as non-respendable if the department does not have the authority to respend the revenue collected; andConsulting with central agencies when assessing the impact of external charging (Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat, Department of Finance Canada and Privy Council Office).

CFOs are responsible for the following:
Ensuring that the authority under which fees are fixed has been identified;Providing the deputy head with assurance that cost estimates for a new or amended fee are reasonable;Ensuring that fees do not exceed the full costs to government to provide the service or regulatory scheme unless the responsible authority may charge fees that exceed costs (for example, proprietary charges);Ensuring that a departmental policy and procedures for granting remissions to fee- payers under section 7 of the Service Fees Act are established and adhered to by:
Ensuring that the departmental remission policy sets out ways to determine whether a service standard is not met and what amount is to be remitted, including but not limited to:
The proportion by which the standard is not met;The impact on the fee-payer of the standard not being met;Any circumstances beyond the department’s control that may impact its ability to meet the standard; and Any role that the fee-payer may play in the standard not being met;Ensuring that the portion of a fee to be remitted is proportional to the degree that the service standard was not met;Ensuring that interest is not paid for remissions made under section 7 of the Service Fees Act and including this practice in the departmental remission policy (section 4.1.6 of the Directive on Payments does not apply to fee remissions);Ensuring that applicable service standards are referenced in the departmental remission policy;Ensuring that remissions are granted to a fee-payer in the form of a refund, a credit, a waiver or other manner acceptable to the department;Ensuring that the form/method of granting remissions to a fee-payer is set out in the departmental remission policy; andEnsuring that the departmental remission policy and procedures are available to the public;Ensuring that annual and periodic fee adjustments are implemented and charged, if applicable, and that the amount of the fee is updated on all departmental websites and documentation by: Ensuring that the anniversary date for the annual adjustment under section 17 of the Service Fees Act is April 1 (in exceptional circumstances, departments may choose a different date for fees in consultation with the Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat);
Ensuring that any change in the anniversary date for a fee pursuant to subsection 17(5) of the Service Fees Act, in consultation with Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat, is published in the departmental fees report before the change comes into effect; Ensuring that the adjustment date for fees subject to other adjustment mechanisms is April 1 (in exceptional circumstances, departments may choose a different date for fees in consultation with the Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat);Ensuring that when fees, that are subject to subsection 17(1) of the Service Fees Act, are rounded down pursuant to subsection 17(4), departments:
Establish and implement a process and procedures to ensure that, when the annual Consumer Price Index adjustment is calculated, the amount of the adjustment is calculated using the non-rounded down amount of the previous year’s fee; Publish the rounded fee in the department’s annual fees report; Ensure that fees that are not based on formulas are rounded down in the following manner:
Fees lower than $51.00 cannot be rounded down; Fees that are between $51.00 to $500.00 are rounded down to the nearest $0.25;Fees that are between $500.00 to $5,000.00 are rounded down to the nearest $1.00;Fees that are $5,000.00 and above are rounded down to the nearest $5.00; Ensure that the elements adjusted by the Consumer Price Index, within the formula-based fees, are rounded down in the following manner:
Formula-based fee elements lower than $51.00 cannot be rounded down;Formula-based fee elements that are between $51.00 to $500.00 are rounded down to the nearest $0.25;Formula-based fee elements that are $500.00 and above are rounded down to the nearest $1.00;Ensuring that fee-payers are consulted when introducing a proposed periodic fee adjustment, in lieu of following the requirement of section 17 of the Service Fees Act;Ensuring that a departmental plan to periodically review activities for which fees are charged is established and implemented, and contains:
The description of the review cycle; The program responsible for the review;The methodology for conducting the review and delivering recommendations for approval;The process and timelines to address and report on corrective actions;Ensuring that an annual report is developed, in accordance with section 20 of the Service Fees Act, regardless of whether or not the Service Fees Act applies, in the manner prescribed by the Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat, excluding fees listed in subsection 2(3) of the Service Fees Act.

CFOs are responsible for the following:
Ensuring that the amount to be charged does not exceed the approved estimate. The rate may exceed the value of related expenditures only if approved by the Treasury Board;Ensuring that Treasury Board approval is obtained for the rates to be charged to client departments for mandatory services that are not funded by appropriations:
Except where the Treasury Board has authorized the department to set rates directly; andEnsuring that rates set for services to Crown corporations or non-federal organizations are consistent with the mandate of the department and do not exceed the full cost to government of providing the service.

Senior departmental managers are responsible for the following:
Working with the CFO to ensure that the fees charged are reasonable and within the department’s authority; Estimating the cost to deliver the service; Ensuring that a written agreement is established and approved by authorized representatives of both departments before services are provided. The written agreement must define the following:
The cost of the service and the rate;The service standard; andAll relevant accountabilities.Ensuring that invoices to client departments have sufficient detail to support client Financial Administration Act section 34 certification.

section.h3: Internal charging for internal support services (section 29.2 of the Financial Administration Act)

clauses.clause:
CFOs are responsible for the following:
Ensuring that interdepartmental charges are made to recover an amount that is equal to or less than incremental costs incurred in providing services, except where:
Charges may be waived where the cost of providing services to the other department is not material.

Senior departmental managers are responsible for the following:
Ensuring that the arrangements between collaborative departments do not result in the transfer of services that are subject to specific legislation or other Treasury Board direction;Ensuring that the proposed activities are administrative in nature and support one of the services listed under section 29.2(4) of the Financial Administration Act;Working with the CFO to ensure that the amounts charged are reasonable and within the department’s authority;Ensuring that a written agreement is established and approved by authorized representatives of both departments before services are rendered. The written agreement must define the following:
The method that will be used to determine the cost of the service; The service standard; and All relevant accountabilities. Ensuring that invoices to client departments have sufficient detail to support client Financial Administration Act section 34 certifications.

CFOs are responsible for the following:
Ensuring that separate accounts are maintained for each revolving fund;Ensuring that financial statements are prepared annually for each revolving fund in accordance with the Government of Canada Accounting Handbook, and with the Public Sector Accounting Standards and the Public Sector Guidelines issued by the Chartered Professional Accountants of Canada (CPA Canada);Establishing and implementing processes for developing and updating the business plan;Ensuring that an annual assessment of the operational and financial performance of the fund occurs in relation to the business plan, and ensuring that remedial actions are taken, if required;Ensuring that the fund will be self-sufficient over its business cycle; andInforming the Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat of any significant changes in the operating environment or in the fund’s financial performance.

Senior departmental managers are responsible for the following:
Ensuring that the business plan is regularly reviewed and updates are provided annually to the CFO;Ensuring that interest is charged for the use of the drawdown authority; Ensuring that Treasury Board approval is obtained prior to seeking parliamentary approval for any matter relating to a revolving fund;Ensuring that Treasury Board approval is obtained for planned changes to key operating aspects of the fund, including changes to the following: The scale and materiality of the activities of the revolving fund; Resources or assets transferred to or from the fund, or obligations assumed or relinquished by the fund; The elements of direct or indirect costs to be charged to the fund, or the basis for allocating indirect overhead costs to the fund; and The basis of fees or rate setting.

CFOs are responsible for the following:
Ensuring that vote wording is provided to the Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat for inclusion in appropriation acts;Seeking parliamentary approval on an annual basis for vote netted revenue authority through an appropriation act;Implementing internal controls to ensure that respendable revenues are used to offset related expenditures incurred in the same fiscal year;Ensuring that revenues are recorded as non-respendable revenue when they are not related to expenditures incurred to provide the service;Seeking Treasury Board approval to offset expenditures using respendable revenue amounts received in a fiscal year in excess of 125% of the amount approved by Treasury Board in the Estimates process; andEnsuring that recoveries of expenditures that are charged to the capital vote are recorded as non-tax, non-respendable revenues.

Senior departmental managers are responsible for the following:
Ensuring that an authority to charge has been confirmed and that Treasury Board approval is obtained for the use of specified revenues to finance activities or programs when seeking vote netted revenue authority from Parliament.

CFOs are responsible for the following:
Obtaining approval from the Receiver General before accepting the related special purpose money when:
A new account for special purpose money is established; A change in the authority is required; or The purpose of an existing account has changed;Ensuring that the use of special purpose money:
Is restricted to payments to third parties or other government departments and, when authorized, temporary costs related to administering the fund; andIs not transferred to other accounts within the department;Once the purpose associated with special purpose money is achieved, ensuring that:
Any balance in the account is returned to the other party; orIf there is no obligation to return the funds to the other party, the balance is transferred to a non-tax, non-respendable revenue account; andThe Receiver General is informed and the account is closed.

Senior departmental managers are responsible for the following:
Accepting special purpose money only when the specified purpose is within the department’s mandate.

CFOs are responsible for the following:
Ensuring that receipts, excluding situations detailed in Appendix A, are credited to only the following:
Statutory appropriations if listed in Appendix A; orLapsing appropriations if listed in Appendix A:
Otherwise, the receipt should be recorded as a refund of a previous year’s expenditure.

CFOs are responsible for the following:
Ensuring that OGD suspense accounts are used only when the department is administering a program on behalf of another department;Ensuring that a written agreement that clearly establishes all relevant accountabilities and identifies all delegation of financial authorities, is approved by authorized representatives of both departments before funds are transferred to the administering department;Ensuring that the funding has been recorded in the OGD suspense account before any expenditures are incurred;Ensuring that the OGD suspense account balance is zero at the end of the fiscal year by returning surplus funds to the partner organization.

Senior departmental managers are responsible for the following:
Confirming with the Privy Council Office that the nature, materiality and duration of the planned arrangement do not warrant a change in the machinery of government.
Not applicable.
This directive applies to the organizations described in section 6 of the Policy on Financial Management.

This directive is issued pursuant to the authorities indicated in sections 7 and 39 of the Financial Administration Act and sections 4, 7, 17 and 20 of the Service Fees Act. The following exemptions apply:
If sections 4 to 6 (service standards) of the Service Fees Act do not apply, subsection 4.3.2 of this directive does not apply;If section 7 (remissions) of the Service Fees Act does not apply, subsection 4.2.4 of this directive does not apply; andIf section 17 (Consumer Price Index) of the Service Fees Act does not apply, subsections 4.2.5.1 and 4.2.6 of this directive do not apply;
Except as otherwise provided in this directive, all other requirements of this directive apply, regardless of whether the Service Fees Act applies.

appendix.title: Appendix A: Standard on receipts that are respendable pursuant to section 39 of the Financial Administration Act

clauses.clause: These procedures take effect on April 1, 2017.
These procedures replace portions of the Directive on Receipt, Deposit and Recording of Money (August 12, 2010).
These procedures provide details on the requirements set out in subsection 4.14 of the Directive on Charging and Special Financial Authorities.

Mandatory procedures are as follows:
Exclusions: Receipts may not be credited to a lapsing appropriation or a statutory appropriation when they are for the following:
A revolving fund; Revenues under a vote netted authority; orSpecial purpose money;Lapsing appropriations: Receipts may be credited to a lapsing appropriation if charged in the same fiscal year as the original disbursement. The receipt against which the related expenditure (advance or payment) was charged must fall within one of the following situations:
Recovery of an overpayment to a supplier;Recovery of a duplicate payment issued to a supplier;Recovery of an erroneous payment to a supplier;Recovery of delinquent account travel card charges that are paid on behalf of the cardholder by the department and recovered from the cardholder or employee;Repayment of an accountable advance;Repayment of a repayable contribution as described in the Directive on Transfer Payments;Refund from the return of goods;Refund of sales or excise taxes and custom duties;Refund of an advance payment;Refund resulting from the settlement of contractual disputes;Refund resulting from a manufacturer’s rebate, price reduction, volume discounts or other price adjustment;Refund resulting from a landlord’s rebate representing a cash lease incentive where a government department is a lessee;Payment received further to an indemnification;Payment received following a claim for loss of or damage to a Crown asset;Rebate resulting from contractual arrangements;Reimbursement from an organization for its agreed share of costs further to a cost-sharing arrangement;Repayment of travel expenses such as personal stopovers and side trips for which charges were included in a departmental invoice but that are the responsibility of the employee or traveller; and Repayment by employees of expenses of a personal nature, such as cellular telephone charges, for which payment was made by the department.Statutory appropriations: The following receipts may be credited to a statutory appropriation in the fiscal year they are received:
Refund of an expenditure;Recovery of an overpayment;Repayment of an advance; andRepayment of a budgetary loan that was originally charged to the statutory appropriation.

dl.dd: A “federal entity,” as defined in the Service Fees Act, or “department,” as defined in the Financial Administration Act.
Services offered by departments that have the mandate to provide services across government (formerly referred to as common service organizations).
An amount charged for the provision of a service, use of a facility, product, regulatory process, regulatory scheme, or conferral of a right or privilege (licence, permit or other authorization).

dt.strong: fee set by contract (frais établis par contrat)

dl.dd: A fee established under a contract between a department (as defined in section 2 of the Financial Administration Act) and an external party.

dt.strong: full cost to government (coût total pour le gouvernement)

dl.dd: The sum of all costs (direct and indirect) incurred by the government in the supply of a good, service, property, or right or privilege.
An increased cost to a supplier’s appropriation resulting from an additional requirement to provide additional goods or services.

dt.strong: other government department suspense account (OGD suspense account) (comptes d’attente d’autres ministères)

dl.dd: An account that allows a funding department to temporarily record funding for an administering department to access and incur expenditures on their behalf.

dt.strong: periodic fee adjustment (rajustement périodique des frais)

dl.dd: A fee adjustment that is made according to an established frequency, based on a specific rate, formula or other factor, other than by section 17 of the Service Fees Act.
Expenditures charged against a departmental spending authority that supports the program that produces revenues where the department has the authority to use revenues to offset related expenditures.

The reimbursement to a fee-payer of a fee or portion of a fee paid in respect of a service, use of facility, right or privilege or regulatory process, for which the department determines the service standard was not met.

Funding mechanisms in which revenues remain available in order to finance continuing operations without fiscal year limitations. In the Government of Canada, revolving funds are used as alternative means of providing funding for specific purposes. The use of revolving funds is appropriate for large, distinct activities that provide client-oriented services where costs can be financed from revenues over a reasonable business cycle.

A public commitment to provide a service, use of a facility, regulatory process, or conferral of rights and privileges, in a way that is measurable and relevant to the fee-payer under normal circumstances. The performance standard referred to in the Service Fees Act is the equivalent of a service standard.

dt.strong: special purpose money (fonds destinés à des fins déterminées)

dl.dd: Monies received or collected from outside parties and deposited in the Consolidated Revenue Fund pursuant to subsection 21(1) of the Financial Administration Act. The money may be disbursed only for the purpose specified in the instrument (such as, act, trust, treaty, undertaking or contract) under which it is received. There has to be a direct link between monies received and monies disbursed, including any interest that may be authorized.

dt.strong: vote netted revenue (revenus nets en vertu d’un crédit)

dl.dd: A lapsing parliamentary authority, provided through an appropriation act under the authority of section 29.1(2) of the Financial Administration Act, that allows a department to spend revenues it receives in a fiscal year through the conduct of its operations to offset related costs incurred in the same fiscal year. This authority is an alternative means of financing activities, which permits departments to finance program or activity costs, either in whole or in part, while any remainder is financed by appropriations.
